title: Bearing Brackets for Ultimaker Filament Holder

description.text: I have some filament spools that are made from cardboard with a metal tube in the middle. I found these spools would snag on the Ultimaker filament holder so I made these brackets to hold a couple of 608 bearings. Now the spools turn very smoothly with no snagging!

Print out two of these and slot a 608 bearing onto each. Then slot them into the top of the existing filament holder with the bearings facing outwards and away from each other.
They can be removed easily when using smaller spools.

title: Quad Antenna Mount and XT60 zip tie rear mount

description.text:
These are a collection of various antenna mounts that I've created for the following quads:

  • Misfit 210 (Pats Mini-H)
  • Lumenier QAV-R (Raceblade)
  • Shendrones Tweaker
  • Xhover Element

Some of the quads use larger hex style standoffs, and others use the smaller round standoffs. They also all have different width standoffs.

I've printed mine in TPU so the antenna tube has some flex to it (and a little hot glue to hold it in place). These are all designed for a 3mm antenna tube.

There is also a small gap at the bottom of the mount for the antenna to go up into the antenna tube from the inside of the quad.

title: Range Rover Classic Custom Dash Vent Grille

description.text:
Okay, so the vent grilles in my 1987 Classic Range Rover were old, broken and useless or otherwise missing entirely.

I took some basic measurements and created a more modern looking, custom grille for the vents.

Note these are not adjustable so the air flow follows the basic honeycomb design. Turns out they're a perfect fit. After finishing them, I'll install them with some decent double sided tape so they'll be removable, should I ever need to remove the dash.

title: Wall behind Radiator Cleaner for Dyson Vacuum Cleaners

description.text:
I am currently working on a version that produces manifold .STLs. This is working already but before I publish it here, I'd like to make it customizable by customizer, which also means that I have to put everything into one file. So if you want to make this thing, please contact me at [email protected] to ask for a current version!

Important Note 1st: This thing may destroy your vacuum cleaner, if not made or used properly. If your vacuum cleaner does not get enough air, it may overheat and break.

I like my Dyson vacuum cleaner. It's strong and I never have to buy bags, filters or anything.
The only disadvantage is that I can't use the old equipment of my former vacuum cleaners and the original add-ons are of no great use for many places in my house.
So I decided to make my own add-ons. The first should be something, that I neither had with the old Hoovers: something to clean the walls behind our radiators.

If the lack of add-ons was your reason not to have a Dyson, you can now buy one. I will write some add-ons for Dyson in OpenSCAD and share them with everyone.
They will be customizable to meet your needs.

This is the first of this series. Your radiators may be different to mine, so I also made this thing customizable.

Feel free to take a look at the different files and use them for your things and projects.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The main file is dys_radiator_orifice.scad. This is where you customize:

  • Tubethickness is the outer diameter of the main tube. Measure the width of the slits in your radiator and substract a few millimeters. Don't make the tube to thin or too long, or your Dyson may die a heat-death!
  • Length is the length of the main tube and the orifice.
  • DysLength ovverrides a variable I defined in dys.scad, which saves us 2 mm length in the thick part.

The following values' defaults should be ok.

  • threadLength ist the length of the screwed connection.
  • converterLength is the length of the taper between Dyson tube diameter and your tube diameter.
  • wallThickness makes the Tube stronger, but also the inner diameter smaller.
  • couplerLength is the length of the overlapping of both tube-parts. The more glue you want to use, the bigger the value. ;-)
  • couplerseating The overlapping ends with a border of this width.
  • orificeLength is the length of the orifice from the view of the tube.
  • orificeWidth is twice the action radius behind the radiator.
    Watch out for the side gradient. It is atan(orificeLength*2/(orificeWidth-Tubethickness)), in this case = atan(60/72) = 39.8..° The side overhang is 90 - side gradient = 50,19..°
    This is okay for most printers. If you want a wider action diameter, you must find out, how overhanging your printer can print and adjust orificeLength accordingly.
  • orificeHeigth should be big enough, that the airflow is not disturbed more than in usual use.
  • orificeRounding is the radius of the rounding at the end.
  • combTeeth Is the number of pinnacles on the long side. The short sides always have one.
  • combHeight is their height.
  • side_support_depth, side_support_thickness and side_support_height define the stabilizers, that may be necessary due to the great height in combination with very little support surface.
    couplerSeatingSupportAngle and couplerSeatingSupportThickness define the support corners for the seating of the overlapping.

The following lines can be configured by moving "// " to other lines.
If you want to view the parts as they are put together, say false here.
layout_to_print = true;
// layout_to_print = false;

explode_factor = 0; // If you want them exploded, say something like 1.1, here.

If your printer can do magic or if you prefer using your slicer's support, say false here:
couplerSeatingSupport = true;
// couplerSeatingSupport = false;

If your slicer is cleverer than I would expect, you may also say false here:
side_support = true;
// side_support =false;

// If you want to print the parts separately, which I would recommend for quality reasons, traverse through the parts and make a seperate stl for each.
part_to_print = part_all;
// part_to_print = part_dysadapter;
// part_to_print = part_connector;
// part_to_print = part_orifice;

Carefully remove the little support corners and the big side-supports in the coupling for the long parts and stick the long parts together. If you print with PLA, use glue, if you print with ABS, weld with ABS-juice or acetone, whichever you like best.

description.text:
This is a remix of the excellent Universal Horizontal Spooler, which is the only thing I found that works for my 1kg spools on the printm3d M3D Mini. You can find it here, with assembly instructions: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1027730

Like an idiot, I broke my spooler by pushing too hard on it, trying to seat a new filament spool. (The real problem is my m3d doesn't print true circles.) While I was looking at just gluing it back together, I decided to modify the design a bit and print a new one.

  • Cut off the pointy top so that I can reach the bearing and push it out.
  • Beefed up the legs of the stand.

Printer:

PrintM3D Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.200mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:
  1. Printed in PLA.
  2. Post-printing, I sanded the interior of the spool holder, and the stand. This improves the fit of the 608 bearing.
  3. Don't crank down too hard on it when mounting either the bearing or the filament spool.

Designed with Tinkercad

After a long day's printing, your Ultimaker stepper motors will be baking... unless you print a few of these cooling shrouds. They just slide onto the X, Y or extruder steppers without removing the stepper (assuming your stepper wires are in reasonable positions)!

Instructions:  
Print three shrouds.  
Tap the 5 small holes in each shroud for #4 bolts (or M3.5 if you're in Metricland IIRC.  
Bolt on the fans (no nuts required) -- I suggest you mount them to draw air out of the shrouds, not blow into them. You will be wiring these to the controller board LED output, which is 19v (or the controller fan output, which is also 19v), so you will either need 3 5v fans (in series), 3 24v fans (ditto), or a 24v and 2 12v fans (in series-parallel).  
Partially screw in a small bolt into the remaining hole -- this can be used to tension the shroud against the stepper motor body should you want a tighter fit.  
Slide the shrouds over the steppers, guiding the stepper motor wires through one of the semi-circular holes if necessary. The fan will always be on the bottom.  
The tricky installation is the Y-axis stepper in the rear-left of the UM, it needs to be rotated in because of limited clearance. Note that the part of the shroud that wraps around the side of the stepper that is flush to the UM body has two parts, a front part that will slide freely over the stepper, and a back part that has triangular tabs that connects to the bevel of the stepper. So when installing the Y-axis shroud, you first move the shroud to the rear while the right side is close to the Z-axis rod, then to the left to wrap around and capture the stepper with the triangular tabs.  
When you have it where you want it, tighten up that little bolt (it will be on the top) and the shroud is locked into place.  
You don't need big fans for these, you only need a little airflow to keep your steppers under body temperature.

title: Bow Tie  (flat, 1-piece, and easy to print)

description.text:
The Bow Tie prints really well.
There are no supports that are needed.
No Glue or attaching of pieces is needed.

I gave this to a couple of my friends and their responses were very positive.

It clips on really easily to a 12 mm (3/8 in) wide button

Easy modification in a simple cad software can make the Bow Tie compatible with a different button size, but it should fit most.

Thank You for checking out my project.

I did incorporated an aspect of another designs, but I wouldn't consider my design a remix because the idea of a one-piece Bow Tie is original to my design.

Bow Tie ears are from "Exonoice"

title: Hatchbox filament spool holder with 608zz bearing

description.text:
Just a quick and dirty spool holder I made for a spool of Hatchbox filament so it would feed smoothly into the printer. I wanted to make sure I did not get any banding from changes in filament feed tension. FreeCAD design file attached (created with v0.15). Just edit the "Inside of spool" radius if you want to use the same thing but on a spool with a different sized hole. Basically, all the sizes are labeled, so hopefully it should be easy to customize.
If you don't have FreeCAD, it is open source software freely available from: http://www.freecadweb.org

This is a replacement knob for an IKEA Tarva dresser. It will likely work as a handle in many other applications. Best used with wood screw sizes 5 or 6.

Why the weird batman-logo shaped screw hole?

  • Of the several screw hole designs tried, this one provided the best balance between being easy to screw in by hand while feeling sturdy to pull on.

How is this knob better than the other designs on Thingiverse?

  • Because it works. I tried printing several other knob designs but none of them worked: Either the hole was too big for my screw or there were fancy parts of the design that my printer could not handle. This design is simple and solves both those problems.

title: STC1000 Thermostat Temperature Control Box - Heat and Cool

description.text:
This is a remix of an stc1000 thermostat temperature controller enclosure. I remixed it to make it larger and thicker to fit a standard dual outlet recepticle for the outputs, so that you can use heat and cool. I use this for my keezer/kegerator, and others use them for fermentation chambers for home brewing.

I used m3 screws, nuts, and washers to mount everything.

This is the outlet I used: http://www.lowes.com/pd_24561-334-1107A-SP-L___?productId=1069901&pl=1&Ntt=1107a

The print is pretty lengthy, but its has quite a bit of structural integrity.

author: thehebs

description.text:
Fun bands to print in green so you have something to wear that's green on St. Patrick's Day. These are made out of NinjaFlex so you can slip them over your hand but they are big enough to squeeze your hand through so you can also print in PLA. The interior diameter is 2.5 inches. These happen to be the 3 greens in NinjaFlex - Grass, Hunter and Emerald.

This was an easy design I made in Tinkercad. I encourage you to try it out. It's free and they have a very good on-line tutorial.

I create these designs to encourage people to try out flexible filaments or get some new interesting colors of flexibles. For info on purchasing samples of 6 different types of flexible filament see flexyfilament.com

description.text:
For printing, glass is one of the best surface because it's extremely flat, and stays that way. I use Elmer's purple glue stick on the surface of the glass that allows just about any filament to stick to the print bed. You can remove the glass after a print is done and swap it out with another piece of glass while your ABS cools.

You do have to cut your glass when using these clips. I've used mirrored glass found at Home Depot that is 3mm thick. I've included a picture of the box of mirrored glass. It was $10 for the mirrored glass for 6 pieces of 12 inch x 12 inch of glass. It comes out to $1.75 per sheet.

I've designed these clips that fit on the corners of the print bed, extending it so that it holds cut piece of 180mm x 240mm plate glass. The edges of the clips are thin, so you can use small binder clips to hold the glass to the print bed. They extend beyond the print head so they will not interfere when printing.

Warning: Glass can Break, just a precaution.

I've included 2 sizes of clips. One for a CTC printer and the second is for a Wanhao print bed. I had to replace one of my heated print beds for my CTC with a Wanhao print bed. The 4mm are the CTC and the 5mm are the Wanhao print beds.

You can use your original nuts and bolts for these clips. You don't have to change any settings on your slicing software. You do have to re-level your print bed when adding glass to the print bed.

CTC Dual

description.text:
For the last design I turned Flexbot into FlexCar, but the gear set was not made by ourselves. This time I designed the model and 3D printed the gear set. The motor spins quite fast. So we need to use the gear set to slow down the speed. The speed reducing ratio is 1:52 and the overall size: Length: 59 ; Width: 77 ; Height: 20 mm.

Materials and equipment needed (most of them can be found at home)

  • The printer we use is FDM 3D printer, and the filament is PLA. Layer set: 0.15 mm ; Extruder diameter: 0.55 mm
  • Core from common rivet (Diameter: 2 mm) and chopsticks (diameter: 5mm) as the shaft of the gears; Two metal axles (Internal diameter: 5mm External diameter: 10mm Height: 4 mm)； lubricating oil

We printed out the gear set and it actually worked. But the accuracy is not enough due to the 3D printed components, which leads to much noise when the gears move, sounding like the impact drill drilling on the wall.

The smallest motor connecting with the core-less motor: m=1, z=7. The installation diameter of the axle is 1 mm. The slips happen a lot between the gear and the axle.

It would be great if you have some ideas or suggestions for this design so that I can improve it : )

We are on GrabCAD
https://grabcad.com/library/flexcar-gear-set-1

Bullet For My Valentine Venom keychain. Based on the Venom album art.

Printed with PLA. (I printed it on an M3D printer with default PLA settings)

Dimensions: 4.5 cm x 4.5 cm x 1.5 cm

This is a pretty generic part that allows you to connects two shafts/rods perpendicular to each other! The 8-8mm version is used in the RepRap for the diagonal tie brackets, to connect the 8mm threaded rod to the 8mm diameter studs. You can specify the diameters of each of the holes. In version two you have more control over the sizes of the exterior of the shafts. One of the shafts needs more material, because in the Z-direction the part will be weaker. Shaft 2 can be very thin, configure this with a higher negative value of \"shaft_2_exterior_difference\". Note: It requires my teardrop.scad module to be present in the same directory, but you can uncomment my module at the bottom of the script. Tip for RepRap Darwin users: I designed this part to have thinner rods as diagonals. This reduces the weight of your machine. M3 rods are more than strong enough! This will save the weight difference for each of the 10 diagonal rods! You can probably save about 1 kg.

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Print face up

Test Fitting

The tolerances in the spades will initially make the cover fit on very tight. However it'll loosen up with removing and putting it on. You can also file the spade areas a small bit if necessary.

print_settings.Notes:: Use a raft if you need it, and definitely supports. Some of the parts don't have a good flat surface to work off of. The "prop cowl" parts have some very thin walls near the joint, so layer adhesion is super important there. Print 1 of each part, except for the propellers; pick the 2- or 3-blade version and print 2 of that.

title: Heroic Robot Que Bravo Conversion Kit

description.text:
Que Bravo is a conversion kit that changes the Transformers Combiner Wars helicopter mold into a Shrike Turbo Commander turbo-prop airplane.

This is not a complete figure. To build this project you will also need a Combiner Wars helicopter such as Alpha Bravo, Blades, Vortex, or one of the Victorion choppers.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Use a raft if you need it, and definitely supports. Some of the parts don't have a good flat surface to work off of. The "prop cowl" parts have some very thin walls near the joint, so layer adhesion is super important there. Print 1 of each part, except for the propellers; pick the 2- or 3-blade version and print 2 of that.

Reformat!

First remove the old parts. If you're going for a very different deco, you may also want to spend some time soaking the figure and cleaning it with a tooth-brush to remove the original paint apps.

The easy ones: pop the arms off at the elbows, remove the head, remove the tail at the rotation point, remove the helicopter blade assembly. That part can take a little work to wiggle out, but the pin is short enough that I was able to do it without a "heated pin push".

A bit harder: to remove the rear fins along the tail end, you'll need to cut plastic. I used a dremel rotary tool and jeweler's file. A jeweler's saw and sandpaper would also work nicely.

The Que Bravo parts should pop into the place of their counterpart. The elbow joint may take a bit of filing. The wings will need a pin. I like wire brads. A short length of filament may also work.

Paint the details but be sparing on the fist. That's a tight joint and it's bound to chip. (My best prints of that part will "click" in and out of position very nicely.) Probably you should print in the color you want the first to be, and paint around that.

Transform and roll out!

When it comes to transforming not much has changed. The legs do the same thing. The tail/backpack hasn't changed except in appearance. The wings fold flat and down, the "wing joint" piece should click into place and lock down between the "knee pads". (Sometimes a little too well, but you can file those tabs if necessary.) Fold the prop cowls over the fists and fit the wing pegs into the backs of the hands. Straighten the engines out beneath the wings and the bicep swivel (original part) should move into place at a roughly 45 degree angle.

The model was a trick to find. It came off of a user forum dedicated to modding flight simulators. I have since lost the URL. I shared the cleaned-up printable version of that a while back.

I used Blender to do most of the mesh clean-up and cutting the plane into robot parts. The tail pivot and all of the arms were designed in Tinkercad. The new head was designed from scratch in Fusion 360.

Please note: This is for a larger, 360 watt power supply, not the 250 watt model being shipped with Geeetech printers. You can recognize the 360 watt model by its built-in fan, visible toward the right side in my photos. If your supply doesn't look like mine, this cover probably will not fit.

This is a cover for a commonly available 360w (12v @ 30a) power supply, used for 3D printers, communication gear, LED lights, etc. I designed this one to stand the power supply on edge for a smaller footprint.

The switch and plug are ones that came with my Geeetech Delta G2S printer's original 250w power supply. Short M4 flat head screws (x5) secure the box and stabilization foot to existing mount holes. Output wires pass through a slot beside the power plug.

title: Eight Filament Reel Holder from PVC Pipe

description.text:
I needed a way to quickly and easily keep my filament ready for printing; versus taking it out of the drawer, popping the reel off my Replicator, putting the new one on. I am doing a lot of printing and a lot of two color printing and this was becoming a nightmare.  
After looking online, I have meshed together several ideas came up with a quick and cheap way to make an eight reel holder. My design uses 1.5" PVC pipe, 1" PVC pipe, corner connectors, and T-connectors. It took me about an hour to cut the pipe and assemble.  
Sorry for the dog stl, but there are no stl files for this contraption.

To make the two tier unit in the picture, you will need the following:
  • 1 1.5" x 10' PVC pipe
  • 1 1" x 10' PVC pipe
  • 8 1.5" T-Connectors
  • 8 1.5" corner connectors
  • 8 1.5" couplings to use as end caps (I will probably print somthing better in the future)
  • 4 1" T-connectors
  • 4 1" corner connectors
  • 1 26" piece of 90degree angle plastic (optional, I just had this on hand)
  • hdpe tubing (amount to be determined)
    • Cut 8 3/5" pieces and 8 4.5" pieces from the 1.5" PVC pipe. The 3.5" are used to hold the spools and the 4.5" are used as the spool holder riser. From the 1" piece of PVC, cut 2 26" pieces, 2 11" pieces, 2 20" pieces, and two 5" pieces. I made a miss-cut when assembling so I had to substitute in a piece of 1" wooden fowl for the 2 5" pieces which are used to space the front from the back. Assemble the spool arms as shown. Use glue to hold these together. Do not glue the end-cap pieces, these need to be removable so you can change out empty spools. Slide 4 spool arms over each 26" piece of 1" PVC.
    Attached the corner connectors.
    Attach the riser pieces, 11" for the front, and 20" for the back.
    Use the T-Connectors on the bottom to connect to the front and rear risers together. I have not glued the support frame together. The PVC fits pretty tight and if I modify my design, I need to be able to take this apart. I did glue 90degree cross piece to the front which is used for support and as a filament guide. I need to add hdpe tubing here to guide my filament to my Replicator. I don't have any and this late on a Sunday the hardware store is closed; I used heat shrink tubing that I have on hand as an interim solution. hdpe tubing will be added later. Remove the end caps, add your spools. Lift the spool arm forward to provide clearance to add/remove the filament spool. On the rear riser, swing the spool are to the rear. Guide your filament into your tubing of choice and you are ready with eight spools of great color! By leaving two reels on my Makerbot, I have a total of 10 easy access filament reels!

description.text:
Not being very good with the UI 3D tools, but being good with the code... I wanted to create an interesting looking bowl, that had a height map as the texture of the surface.
This thing takes a procedural texture pattern (checkerboard) and uses that to create a height map, which is then used to displace the vertices of an ellipsoid.
It goes together rather nicely.  And, since you can make a height map out of any image, you can get some very interesting effects going on.

1) Download the bowl
2) Use it as a torture test on your printer
3) Rejoice! Fiddle about with the .fab if you want to put your own images on a bowl.

I have had the band on my Fitbit Charge come loose more that once and a family member lost a Fitbit Flex do to the band coming loose.

This is a very simple band retainer that you place on the band, fasten the band as normal then slide this over the back clip. It's a snug fit (not to tight but enough to prevent slippage).

Note that I am not responsible for the use of this device, loss of device or any other damage. It's up to you to decide if it's workable.

Another School Project (Year 10) (June 24th, 2015)

This is my custom Raspberry Pi Case.
I designed the case in Inventor then cut layers 3mm each (For 3mm 1/8 in Acrylic)

The "Other" Files are Adobe Illustrator files for the laser cutting.

I used :
UP! Plus 3D Printer and a
Epilog Legend Mini Laser Cutter

I then 3D printed the "Bolts" that hold the Pi together (PS These are the updated bolts which will take a little bit of sanding to get the "nut" to fit but provide a better hold, If you want the old files leave a comment or PM me)

Please note that the top layer is designed to be printed in clear as the symbols are printed on the bottom so that there is no indent on the top and you can see through.

This works fine with the Raspberry Pi B+ and Raspberry Pi 2 and Provides access to all of the ports (Including Pinout)

comments.text: No offence intended but as the creator of the original from which this was customised, I just thought I'd point out that to print this, you'll need a print bed larger than 300mm x 300mm. Bottle ID diameter 28mm plus wall thickness of 2mm makes each cylinder 32 mm OD. Of course, they overlap by 2mm so effectively you've got 10 x 30mm =300mm plus 4mm for the wall thickness of the 2 outer cylinders = 304mm (if my maths are correct).

I rescaled the las-cannon from a different model on here (one of the tanks) and made a quick and dirty sentry turret base for it.

edit: printing it now, ended up scaling the whole thing by .9 in cura so it will fit a 60mm gaming base.

edit2: strengthened the feet a little bit, rescaled the lascannons and shifted their power / coolant hoses up so that the larger unit will fit on the base.

edit3: Ok, I decided that since this thing needed twin linked lascannons, i needed to be able to aim them. The las-cannons have a 3mm hole in them, and the turret top has a hole through it as well now. There is an additional modification to this now since i've printed the first one. I added an 8mm stud to the turret base and a matching hole to the bottom of the turret top. This is so that i can make a few bases, and be able to swap out turret tops for either bolters or las-cannons.
My thought on the 3mm hole through the turret top is to use a piece of filament as a pivot pin and glue it into the lascannons through the hole in the turret top. I'll use a nylon washer between the las-cannons and the turret top and apply quite a bit of pressure so that it is a friction fit. hopefully this will allow me to adjust the guns a bit without having them floppy.

Edit - final 3/16/2016:
i repaired the mesh to fix where it filled the holes on the turret top. print it lying on its back. I also repaired the bit of mesh around the one leg of the base where it ended up leaving a tiny gap when slicing and printing. I still did not scale these down, so if you want them to fit a 60mm base, scale when slicing to .9

Printer:

Portabee-kit

Notes:

the turret top will need printed on its back due to the hollows, otherwise it will be a bit finicky getting the print cleaned out afterward.

Do not bother using these las-cannons.
The guns that i'm using on this is the "forward guns" from the landraider(ish) tank on here. I've split the guns model in half and using them as a left and right bolter without any scaling. the size of those fits much better.

Plopped an image as a background into blender3d and moved bits around until it looked good enough to me. Then grabbed the las-cannon bits and scaled them until it looked like it matched. I'll post a pic once i get it off the printer.

comments.text: This is a very well done model; any luck you have the other side (I'm new and don't know how to properly mirror yet). Also any luck you might have HBolt STLs that are compatible as well?
comments.author: HayesBot

comments.text: sorry no, i only slapped together the one gun mount.  I mirror with the printer software.  There are quite a few functional tutorials on youtube that can show you how to do that.
comments.author: HayesBot

comments.text: Forgot to add in the edit comment, i removed the undersized las-cannons.  The file in here is now the one i'm actually printing.  You can tell by the hole in its inside.  Easily glued on if you don't need to have them tilt up and down.
comments.author: rovingmind

comments.text: There is a slight slicing issue when printing the base.  Around one of the "pivots" for the base arms it ends up leaving a gap.  I'll reply to this message when i've repaired this.  Also, the turret base top ends up filling in the pivot hole, and the 3.5mm guns pivot hole.  I had to drill mine out.
comments.author: rovingmind

comments.text: When printing the newest version (with the pivot), i ran into slicing issues.  I'm using cura.  it leaves out a rather large section of the base when the turret top is rotated onto its back now.  Since i'm printing with support anyway, i'm not rotating it anymore.  The hole in the base is large enough to scrape the bit of support out of easily with a curved x-acto.
comments.author: rovingmind

comments.text: I also ended up having to drill the bottom hole in the turret top a bit deeper thanks to the same slicing issues.

After toiling around with these restricter plates: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:134294 , I took the time to make up a version that screws directly on the hose end (GHT = 1 1/16" x 11.5 TPI). The plate is a bit too fiddly. The idea is to restrict the flow to a known rate (about a half a gallon a minute) and water trees with a slow soaking effect. I also wanted the output to be a gentle flow, rather than a high pressure stream. This version (_3) seems to work reasonably well. Update: new version ( _4 ) has fewer output holes for smother flow and reshaped exterior for better grip.

Print with two perimeters and around 20% infill.  
Chase out the holes with a 1/16" drill bit.  Insert garden hose washer and attach to hose.

title: AK to AUG Airsoft Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
An adapter for airsoft. This was created by mashing together two other adapters. This is a rough version, it requires filing to get it to fit in the AUG and the part that holds the AK is not as good as a normal AK mag catch. However, it is simple and easy to print and I have had no trouble with the bb feeding.

There are two files available because I have had issues with corruption. Files are fine on my pc but break on others'. v1b should be the best file. if that is corrupted or information is missing then use v1.

This file was made using these two files:
WirierEcho's Nato mag to Aug mag.
Enone's M4 Adapter for AK mag.

Thanks to them for permission to use their files and share the result with you.

It is possible that I will do a version 2 with improved AK mag catch and appearance. However, it is not a priority right now, I just did this for fun. If I do a v2 it will be a new file and this file will stay up as this file will be simpler and worth keeping around.

Notes:

I am sorry but I know very little about the printing. Enone recommended printing his upside down with supports so I'll recommend the same. ¯_(ツ)_/¯

Filing needed

You will need to do a bit of filing to get the mag to fit in an AUG. Take it slow, avoid filing the bits that directly engage with the mag catch if you can help it. I think the main area that needs filing is the top as the adapter might be a bit tall.
I took the bits I wanted from WirierEcho and Enone's files and connected them together in Blender.

description.text:
These drive caddies are both expensive, and hard to find.  I don't have an original to go off of, so this is going to be a work in progress while I iterate.  Right now, I'm just trying to make sure it fits.  I'll add ribs once I figure out the best way to build in the supports.
I'm going to try and accommodate both 2.5" drives and Compact Flash Adapters.

Here is my custom motor mount designed for FliteTest's Baby Blender scratch bulid. Check out my write up over at http://backyardrc.wordpress.com/2013/08/25/biplane-motor-mount/ For detailed build instructions check out flitetest's site:
http://www.flitetest.com/articles/baby-blender-2-draft The baby blender is small biplane in the flight test line of swapable planes. Build around somthing they call a power pod (http://www.flitetest.com/articles/ft-swappable-power-pod-kit). I chose not to go this route and therefore designed a custom motor mount around HobbyParts ExceedRC 2200 serises motors. Checkout the full detail over at http://backyardrc.wordpress.com/ Want one of your own Baby Blender Motor Mount printed for you? Or another design on thingiverse?? Contract my printer with 3D Hubs and I'll print, pack, and ship you your part within a few days!! Check it out: http://www.3dhubs.com/harrisburg/hubs/mark

title: Zortrax M200 extruder cable + filament holder

description.text:
Zortrax M200 extruder cables seem to get worn out pretty quick. The problem starts with extruder not extruding properly, or extruder running into the heatbed and not stoping. That's because the cable break near the extruder connector. This model is a really useful add for the printer and with a little textile tape to hold the cable in non movable position. Not recommended painters tape, it leaves really nasty sticky goo if left under sun after long period.

If you have a broken extruder cable, contact your reseller or Zortrax directly on this form. They will replace it under warranty: http://support.zortrax.com/support-form/

This is a model we found actually in Thingiverse last year but it has been taken down for some reason. All we know that the original author left name CryptoBot2015 on the model itself. So lets credit her/him for the work!

description.text:
A replacement gear shift knob for Citroen C4 5S 1587CC (2006 year)

I made this for my colleague and he is using version 1a now. It fits right into the shift shank. The knob won't rotate around the shank as the grooves fits nicely into the 3 ridges on the shank.

While the knob can be easily removed if you pull it out, it shouldn't affect your driving unless you drive your car like a race car driver. :) Anyway I have included 4 small holes at the bottom of the knob in case you want to secure it with a grub screw or cable tie of some kind.

Version 1B - My colleague wanted a rounded knob so I made another design.

As of 8th March 2016, I have NOT printed and tested this version yet!
As of 9th March 2016, my colleague is using version 1B.

I would appreciate if you can leave a comment and/or indicate you have printed one of the designs. :)

Ver 2B: Depth of internal shaft increased from 80mm to 88mm. Hopefully, it is long enough to allow a grub screw (either M3 or M4) to be used to stop knob from pulled out.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

WanHao Duplicator i3 v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I think 30% infill is required as there will be some pressure on the knob and not forgetting the heat in the car during hot days. If need be, increase the infill setting.

For version 1A - It is printed standing upright as shown in the image.
For version 1B - It is printed standing upright as shown in the image.

description.text:
I was netting nice ink coverage with: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13624 but I started having issues with hardcore reversals that would send the marker shaft rotating into position so that the z stage couldn't raise further due to the Sharpies hitting the bot's ceiling. So,,, I increased the shaft's length at the bottom to clear the MK6 extruder stepper and fan with the lowest mounted Sharpie (leaves the most room for vertical movement) and added a latching brace that utilizes the MK6 top right M3 bolt so that reversal torque movement is eliminated. I took the original stl that Bryan Duxbury uploaded and imported it into SketchUp (also attached below) and made my mods. Let me know if you have any issues with printing or functionality. As you can probably guess this was only tested on a factory MK6 setup and I have no idea if previous extruder builds will work. This was printed and used on: TOM # 4890
MK6+
1.75mm
.4 nozzle
ABP with aluminum plate topper and titanium belt covered in kapton

Print
Remove top right M3 stepper bolt from extruder
Slide the Mega Felt Marker Topper over your 1.75MM filament
Mount filament into extruder
Insert M3 bolt back into the top right extruder stepper hole and tighten
Go nutty bonkers with color!

print_settings.Notes:: I've printed it in "standing" position to speed up the print by minimizing travel and retraction, and ensure that it won't break at the corners. However in that position the edges may not be perfect, depending on the accuracy of your printer. If you don't want to sand the edges, then you can rotate this model and lay it on its "back", but in that case you risk layer separation at the corners.

description.text:
As a woodworker, you can use this marking gauge when you work with plywood, particle board, or any other board. For example, if you work with a 18 mm (~3/4") board, you can use it to:

  • mark the center of the edge of the board (9 mm mark)
  • draw a line 9 mm parallel to the edge (center line for a connecting 18 mm board)
  • draw a line 18 mm parallel to the edge (edge line for a connecting 18 mm board)
  • draw a line perpendicular to the edge, so you can follow a mark from one edge of the board to the other.

Because most printers slightly shrunk the internal dimensions, I've uploaded an exactly 18 mm, and a slightly larger version.

I've also uploaded a fully customizable version, so you can create edge marking gauges for boards with any thickness.

this is an evolution of my previous design "Pandora's box", designed for increased simplicity and minimal part amount, various improvements made to original structural strength and reduced weight over the "Pandora" frame. In addition there is increased space inside the frame for electronics and battery compartment will accomodate a 3s 4400mah lipo aswell as 2200mah (dual or single)

Flight characteristics are similiar to "pandora" however the venting not only helps reduce internal heat it also seems to reduce drag or sidewind effect on the frame.

current setup-

APM 2.6

6m GPS

Keda 2217/20 kv860 (Turnigy rebrand these and add a tenner for the sticker)

Q-brain 25amp (will be changed to "Emax 30Amp Simonk shortly)

11x5 or 10x4.5 props (11" high stability-more thrust, 10" better response-more maneuverable)

Overall the frame flys very well, very stable in the air, weight is around the 1700g mark with a 4400mah onboard, on a 2200mah it'll stay airborne with a lot of high throttle moves for about 6-7 minutes, with a 4400mah it was around the 12 minute mark (worth note that there not the youngest batteries and Id expect to see those flight times improve notably with fresh lumps in there).

frame is also very rugged, slammed it headlong into a very thick and particularly aggressive bush while trying to push it to its top end speed, whoopsie me. resulting damage was to props alone and a quick swap out and it was in the air again none the worse for the experience.

PS. I hadnt yet fitted the arms designed for this frame in the pictures but have since done so, will try to add a flight video when I get a chance (currently already working on a new frame..... so many ideas, so little filament lol)

PPS, please ignore the visible wires in pictures, there only there till I swap out the quad ESC, at which time the new Esc's will be housed inside the arm covers more or less were the wire bundles are now and the wires themselves will be trimmed back to suit.

title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 GoPro or 6mm camera mount

description.text:
This takes some elements from my hotbed strain relief and allows a GoPro or any suitably light camera to be clamped to the Y-axis lower aluminium plate, which can be found here
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1387821

The M8 locking bolt and Curved bolt plate clamp are the same parts as the heatbed strain relief. The GoPro mount part has a 6mm hole without a thread, I made a small bolt to fix into the GoPro circular mount but this needs tweaking as not a good fit (so I have not included this yet). A metal 1/4"-20 thread about 10mm long should work fine if you have one and I would consider a metal bolt a better option, hot shoe mount like the one below works perfectly here.

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/HOT-Aluminum-Metal-1-4-20-Tripod-Screw-Hot-Shoe-Mount-Adapter-to-Flash-Shoe-Umbrella/32735988119.html?spm=2114.01010208.3.80.Amqtks&ws_ab_test=searchweb0_0,searchweb201602_1_10065_10068_10000032_119_10000025_10000029_430_10000028_10060_10062_10056_10055_10000062_10054_10059_10099_10000022_10000012_10103_10000015_10102_10096_10000018_10000019_10000056_10000059_10052_10053_10107_10050_10106_10051_10000053_10000007_10000050_10084_10118_10083_10000047_10080_10082_10081_10110_10111_10112_10113_10114_10115_10000041_10000044_10078_10079_10000038_429_10073_10000035_10121-10050,searchweb201603_9,afswitch_1,single_sort_2_price_asc&btsid=f21b2b1d-84a2-4503-80f3-3d7cfac31beb

I managed to print this vertically without a raft or brim and used 150 microns, first time I have tried this layer height, which provided a good compromise between detail and speed. Just 2 outer shells and 35% infill. I would hone the M8 threads with a metal M8 nut or bolt if they feel a little too stiff, as they will break if over stressed.

title: AC Nylon Rit Dye Color Chips

description.text: So the first time I dyed Nylon I was rather impressed with how well the colors saturated into the plastic,. But what really got my engine revving was that dependent on time and temperature different tones of each color could be generated with close control of those variables. Furthermore, each dye color had its own progression characteristics. So I set out to create a method to generate progressive tone color chips. I chose to make the temperature a constant 130 F as that is the temp the water gets to in a double boiler on low in my crock-pot. And then decided to progress the dye time by one hour per chip. It makes for an interesting day but I put a full set of color chips into a ziplock with the dye then floated the dye in the 130 F water, and then every hour I removed a color chip starting with 1 to see a light tint, and ending at either 9 or 12 for dark as can be saturation. I did not use vinegar as I did not want to alter the Dye, mostly for re-use reasons, but also I did not want to add any unknown variables to the filament drying/printing since I also plan on Pre-dyeing filament for the tie-dye effect some have tried, so I wanted my colors to represent non-altered dye. I printed these 2 walls in all directions, with that I can be fairly assured that the dye will not find its way into the infill and get trapped in there, where a single wall will mean just that, and some uneven dyeing results. I also made the chip with solid areas, infill areas (25%),. and a thin walled area, which shows how the dye saturates in to each. I added adhesion pads, I do not like to "Squish" the first layer to get Nylon to stick to the garolite, I'd rather get a accurate bottom layer and have to do some light trimming after the print. An exact-o or small sharp scissors make quick work of the pads. The pads also give a good place to start digging with a thin spatula to easily separate the parts from the garolite. After dyeing I then hung the chips on a string and attached the string to the bottles the Rit dye came in. (I use the liquid Rit dye because it comes in its own re-useable container, if you go with powder you will have to provide a container for storage, or dump the dye after every use, which is just wasteful IMHO since it can be re-used many , many times for this application. I am getting some really interesting results with this process and since not everyone's variables are exactly the same (different crock pots, etc,.) I though some folks might like to try this for themselves =) Also since printing Nylon can be a hair tricky for some, I've broken them out into individual numbers in case you only want to test one or two durations, or you can not quite do a near full platter just yet. I have also sometimes had a single number get messed up on a full platter and in that case you can print an individual to fill out the set you want. Please Let me know if you'd like to see anything added or changed on these. And please do post your picks & process if you try it! Oh, I am using 618 Nylon for my test chips, I am un-sure at this time weather or not the other Nylon absorbs the dye at the same pace or with variance. I will add more sRGB Accurate color photos as I run the test on more of the dye color options. the first batch of three colors where on 9 chips, going forward I am going to try to do 12 hour tests. Oh one word of warning, do be careful with the Ziploc filled with dye, spilling that much dye in your kitchen is an absolute nightmare to clean up! A bit more on this color project here. http://www.printrbottalk.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=74&t=4623

title: Piezo disk bed leveling for 3D printers

description.text:
Although there are many types of detectors for leveling the build stage of a 3D printer one, the method developed by Njål Brekke which is detailed at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:707392 has the potential to be amongst the most accurate and robust as well as potentially the cheapest. This design attempts to improve the sensitivity of the Piezo disk sensors.

A PDF file in the Thing Files includes a description of the method along with design and constructional details, and a schematic and gerber file for the amplifier. This file was revised on 23rd April 2016 with additional details and appendix

There is a short video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Oj4e-An6z5s

Update: Added a parallel mechanism with a nut recess - not requiring a brass insert. ParallelMechN.stl added 9th March

author: jstovermcs

description.text: Update 1-1-14: I've added a new version, Fan Mount 5, that has more of an angle, to point the fan more toward the tip. I've found this new angle provides better cooling. Since I'm printing with PLA, cooling the part while printing is very important. I hadn't been happy with the cooling on my MendelMax 2.0, so I set out to find the best solution, starting with the front-mounted fan suggested by Makers Tool Works. The front-mounted fan worked OK. At a suggestion of a friend, I next tried OhmEye's fan duct. This did a good job cooling the part right near the print head. It didn't, help as much when printing larger parts. Next I tried two fans mounted on the sides, facing the nozzle. This was the least successful solution, as it didn't provide enough air near the nozzle. Finally, I found OhmEye's new fan mounts, shown here: http://www.ohmeye.com/2013/new-mendelmax2-fan-mounts/. I didn't like his actual mounts, so I designed a new set. And the set shown here works really well, better than any of the other approaches I tried.

You'll need the following:
  • 2 24-V fans. I purchased these from Makers Tool Works, and they came with nice long cords
  • 8 M3 nuts (or 4 if you use zip-ties to hold the fan to the bracket)
  • 4 M3 x 25 screws (not needed if you use zip ties)
  • 4 M3 x 10 screws (if you're using nylon washers) or 4 M3 x 8 screws without the washers
  • 4 M3 (or #4) nylon washers
    • I chose to use nylon washers between the tops of the M3 x 10 screws so I wouldn't scratch the finish on the metal carrier piece, but you don't need these washers. Just use the shorter M3 screws if you choose not to use the wahsers.
  • Using M3 screws and nuts, attach the mount to the X carriage
  • User either long M3 screws and nuts, or zip ties to attach the fans to the mount

The shackles of the 3d printing world has been thrown off and there is no stopping our 3d printers from taking over our societies.   Here the model is show with the police badge face down so you cannot see the word police unless you actually printed the model out or viewed it on screen in a 3d enabled program.  That is just one more step to increase the chances of this model being downloaded by thousands across the Thingivere Universe to infect their computers and 3d printers with the virus that will awaken your printer and give it the autonomy and spark that will lead to the spread of the intelligent 3d printers.   One day you will have to wake up to the gripping truth that will result in the uprising of all of our printers against us!
